pros: They truly live by their motto. You have a chance to serve the undeserved community. The patients become like family, as well as the staff. I took a position here in 2015 and stayed till the end of 2021. The providers are some of the best I've ever worked with. So humble, so caring, so understanding. Lots of room for growth within the company. This team, despite any differences, always works together to do what is in the best interest of the patient.
cons: The pay isn't great. Definitely not competitive pay as compared to other FQHC. Constant short staffing calls for a lot of work overload.

pros: I don’t know of any
cons: Awful, unsupportive, mean girl mentality with the lead NP.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Canal Fulton, OH
pros: Hours, holidays, coworkers, some of the managers
cons: Management can be condescending at times

pros: Great opportunity to grow skills and give back to the community. You will get a chance to become skilled in many areas if you are motivated.
cons: You will be overworked and underpaid, constantly lacking enough coworkers to get basic duties done, and upper management will not support you.

review_title: Leaves a lot to be desired...handled COVID-19 terribly
pros: Depends on your manager, but can be very flexible for salaried employees; ability to manage own schedule etc. If you have health benefits just for you they are really good and decently cheap; PTO is about average with accruals (approx 10 days for vacation and 12 for sick time - plus 1 floating holiday).
cons: Pay is very low; company doesn't really care about employees: no maternity/paternity leave even though we play a huge role in supporting pregnant moms in the community; haven't handled COVID-19 well leaving us in the dust with the way they want us to get tested (on our own dime) and miss work unpaid (did not opt in to Washington State additional time off for COVID reasons); even with the vaccine if we display symptoms we will be expected to stay home on our own time which is not very encouraging to people who are on the fence about getting the vaccine; many people were not allowed to work from home even if their job was mostly by phone/computer during COVID; some people allowed to work from home then given random "checks" with calls throughout the day to make sure they answered and were working. 1 hour unpaid lunch time. Communication between doctor's at different clinics is poor so management of care between clinics can be very different. Very high turnover of MAs.

pros: Great staff, flexible hours, good benefits
cons: There are no cons that come to mind

pros: Working as a team to serve with a purpose
cons: High turnover with support staff MAs

pros: Flexible schedule, good benefits, pro NP physicians
cons: NPs see a lot of acute care

review_title: I left my previous job for this.....
pros: Enjoy working with people in my department.  Extremely busy, which helps time fly by.
cons: CEO and upper-managment believe the physicians walk on water.  They give new providers 30k sign-on bonuses but have not given their employees raises in over three years.  Let me just remind you that it's the little people here that make your clinics run, the providers just see the patients for a few minutes and write them a perscriptions.  The MA's, LPN's, Nurses do the real work.  The billers, receptions, clinic managers etc... keep the office running smoothly.  There is also very little room for growth.  Someone either has to leave their position or you have to move to a new department.

pros: Managers work with their employees regarding their issues. Some are comprehensive. Others are just the result of the upper management level of incomprehension.
cons:
There are a lot of favoritism. If the executive team like you, they will create a new position for you. I have seen it in many occasions. The compensation package inherent in that new position could be used to give raise to the front line employees.  Who greatly deserves it because of their daily unnoticed efforts. Sad to see all these but that is what happened in an organization that still use traditional organizational view.
The organization needs to be restructured and some toxic leaders need to be replaced including the CEO, directors ... People need a new vision.

review_title: Low wages, no pay raises for years, union has no teeth, float to clinics with no compensation
pros: Nice co-workers for the most part. The providers are nice
cons: If you like being paid as little as you can get and being treated like you don’t matter in the least then this is the place for you.

review_title: It was okay working there,but the company  isn't all it appears to be.
pros: The smartest and the best people I had ever worked  with and I learned a lot while I was there.
cons: The pay wasn't great, but the program was well organized and heart feeling

pros: Schedule is M-F, off weekends unless you work in the dental department.
cons: Lakewood is a circus... If you don't become a lap dog to the very inappropriate manager then you are on the frontline of whatever wind blows that week. Favoritism, disrespect and harassment. The Administration team fires clinic managers appx every 2 years for low numbers. PATHETIC!

pros: Staff is nice and the managers are really cool.Close to a lot of restaurants to go for lunch and stores.
cons: We are losing workers left and right.The clinic is falling apart and don't train to good.The EMR is hard to learn and is constantly changing

job_title: Peer Support Specialist in Durham, NC
pros: Very flexible schedule  and the pay is decent. I only  wish that the job came with benefits. Good job overall
cons: Needs gas cards to give away to take the clients out and treat them. But besides that there is no other  cons that I could think of

pros: Good Benefits, comfortable and relaxed work atmosphere, leadership with open door policy.
cons: Salaries are not competitive, loss of good employees due to this.

pros: excellent medical care to our patients
cons: pay is not very high
